interlinear-text.item: ELA Historical Sites of the Pamir Region

phrase.item: When it comes to our historical places
left to us from the past,
starting from Ishkashim and Rin, in each village there are fortresses and holy places, all the way to Ratm [Wakhan].
Our lands went even farther than Ratm in the past,
to Aqba, and Imkhona and [?]. Our people were all the way out there in the past, and [their] graves still exist there.
This also tells us about what kind of place and location this was in the past.
From ancient times, starting from the sixth century, the Wakhan appeared in history.
Travelers would come from China
and India, to learn about and discover the Wakhan and Pamir.

At first, for those of Chinese descent, Wakhan [was known as] as 'Bogho', as 'Domested'. Under such names it was known. [During] the time when travelers [caravans] used to come, this place was a country, with a king. They also had an army, they had everything.
Today, the fortresses are the evidence of those times.

As you see today in Tajikistan the [Pamir] region is far away in the corner, however back in that time, it was a big country, there were governors, civilization, culture, a military and everything. Today our historical places are getting destroyed, and disappearing.
For instance, a fortress we have in Namadgut, which is the biggest fortress in the Pamir, is called Qaqa.
Today that place is becoming damaged by the wind and rain, so it's slowly disappearing.
Or, with other fortresses in Yamchun it's the same, they are becoming damaged by the rain and wind, so they too are disappearing.
Another great ancient treasure we have, are the stone faces and rocks that have been written upon.
One of the biggest [petrogylph areas] in Central Asia is in Langar village. Today even that place is in danger and about to go away.

Our sisters and brothers, whether they are aware of it or not, are destroying it with their own hands. They are writing their names on top [of the old ones] and they are writing their date of birth there [covering up the old writings and markings].
In Langar there are images, signs and and other things that are very old.
They are from the Stone and Bronze Ages. The Bronze Age was a very long time ago.
From the times of Ashoka, we find writings there.
Unfortunately, today people are not valuing them and destroying them with their own hands.
On top of natural disasters such as hurricanes and rain, people are also destroying them. This shows that eventually we will lose our history by our own hands.
We will lose our identity.
We will lose it and nobody will know about it.
Today, these [historical places] are the reason that many tourists and guests come here. We proudly show them such places.
I deeply request of my sisters and brothers that whatever treasures we have, we should preserve them.
Together we must all do our best not to let them disappear.
